title: Understanding the Concept of a Limit
text: To give a little background on Limits and its origin, the concept of a limit was first introduced in the 1600's by Sir Isaac Newton. Mathematicians practicing Calculus needed a way to determine the rate of change (\(\Delta\)) between two points on a curve that were infinitesimally apart so that they could find the Instantaneous Rate of Change (the rate of change at a point on a curve) Thus, came the introduction of Limits that helped determine that the \(\Delta\) between two points that are infinitesimally apart could be determined as long as the points were on the same curve or were at least on an adjacent curve. This introduces another concept known as Continuity which will be briefly discussed in another section. You might find the concept itself a little tricky to understand at first, but with a little practice and time you will start to understand the concept and its purpose.

title: The Formal Definition of a Limit
text:
The following definition of a limit is something that will take a little time to really sink in so don't worry too much if you don't understand it at first.

$$\text{Given a function $f(x)$ that is defined on an open interval $(a, b)$}$$
$$\text{We can find the $\bold{limit}$ of $n$ where $n \in (a,b)$}$$
$$\lim\limits_{x~ \to ~n} f(x) = L$$
$$
\text{If for every $\epsilon \gt 0$, there exists a $\delta \gt 0$ such that}
$$
$$
\text{if $0 \lt \lvert~ x ~-~n ~\rvert \lt \delta$ $\quad$ then $\quad$ $\lvert ~ f(x) ~ - ~ L ~ \rvert \lt \epsilon$ }
$$
$$ \text{When we find the limit $L$, we say the limit of $f(x)$ as $x$ approaches $n$ is $L$} $$

title: Understanding Limits by Example
text:
Consider the following, $$\text{Given $f(x) = x$, find} \lim\limits_{x~ \to ~2} f(x) $$ To give a quick representation of what finding the limit means, take a look at the following table
\(f(x) ~~ \text{where} ~~ x \gt 2 ~ \text{(approaching 2 from the right)}\)\( f(x) ~~ \text{where} ~~ x \lt 2 ~ \text{(approaching 2 from the left)} \)
\(3\)\(1\)
\(2.5\)\(1.5\)
\(2.1\)\(1.9\)
\(2.01\)\(1.99\)
\(2.001\)\(1.999\)
As you can see, as \( x \) approaches \( 2 \) from the left and right (think of a number line), \( f(x) \) is converging towards \( 2\). Keep in mind that the function \( f(x) = x \) is a continuous function meaning that it contains no breaks or jumps for any value of \(x\), from which we can conclude that \( f(x) \) converges to \(2\) as \(x \rightarrow 2 \). $$\text{Given $f(x) = x$, the limit of $f(x)$ as $x$ approaches $2$ is $2$}$$ $$\text{formal notation:} \lim\limits_{x~ \to ~2} f(x) = 2 $$ To further elaborate on the answer, take a look at the graph of \(f(x) = x \). You can see by inspection that as \(x\) gets closer to \(2\), \(f(x)\) also gets closer and closer to \(f(2) = 2\).
